settings.text: An antifungal drug is called Mycelex-3. It fights fungus-related infections.Yeast infections of the vagina are treated with Mycelex-3.Users of Welzo can use this article for informational purposes to better understand Mycelex-3.

Yeast infections of the vagina affect many women. They can make the vagina and vulva itch, burn, and turn red. Antifungal medications that are ingested or applied directly to the vagina as creams or suppositories are typically used to treat vaginal yeast infections.

Mycelex-3's most frequent negative effects include:

Headache

Dizziness

upset stomach

These are Mycelex-3's most frequent side effects. If you experience any side effect that bothers you or does not go away, speak with your doctor.

The typical Mycelex-3 dosage for vaginal yeast infection is as follows:

For seven days, take one tablet orally three times per day.

Speak to your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions about dosages. They can assist you in determining your personal optimal dose.

Other medications, vitamins, or herbs you may be taking may interact with mycelex-3. When a substance modifies how a drug functions, there is an interaction. This could be harmful or stop the medication from working properly.

Your doctor needs to carefully monitor all of your medications to help you avoid interactions. Tell your doctor about all of the drugs, vitamins, and herbal remedies you are taking. Speak with your doctor or pharmacist to learn how this medication may interact with other medications you are taking.

The following medicines are a few examples of those that can interact with mycelex-3:

Tetracyclines

antibiotics with macrolides

quinidine

warfarin

The drugs listed here are not all those that could interact with Mycelex-3. Combining this medication with any of these medications may increase the risk of certain side effects.

Mycelex-3 is a member of the azole antifungals drug class. A class of drugs is a collection of drugs with similar mechanisms of action. Similar conditions are frequently treated with these medications.

Mycelex-3 works by eliminating or inhibiting the growth of fungi. It accomplishes this by preventing the fungi from producing an ingredient known as ergosterol. A crucial component of the fungal cell membrane is ergosterol. Without it, the fungi die and their cells rupture.

Mycelex-3 is efficiently absorbed from the digestive system. After oral administration, peak plasma concentrations happen 2 to 3 hours later. Mycelex-3 has an elimination half-life of 8 to 10 hours.

In body fluids and tissues, Mycelex-3 is widely dispersed. (Less than 10%) Plasma protein binding is low.
